efficiency_definition.title: Energy Transformation Efficiency
efficiency_definition.content: Efficiency measures how much of the theoretical energy was actually captured as useful energy. In calorimetry, we compare the heat absorbed by water (experimental) to the energy that should have been released by the fuel (theoretical from data tables).
keyPoints: Efficiency is always less than 100%
Experimental value goes in the numerator
Theoretical value comes from data tables (ŒîHc)
Low efficiency means energy was lost

heat_loss_effect.title: Heat Loss and Efficiency
heat_loss_effect.content: Heat escaping to the surroundings is the main reason experimental efficiency is less than 100%. This heat never reaches the water, so it isn't measured, reducing the experimental value.
keyPoints: Heat radiates away from flame and can
Wind or drafts increase heat loss
Insulation and lids reduce heat loss
Lost heat reduces the experimental value

incomplete_combustion_effect.title: Incomplete Combustion
incomplete_combustion_effect.content: When combustion is incomplete, products like carbon monoxide (CO) and soot (C) form instead of carbon dioxide. These products still contain chemical energy, so less energy is released than theoretical.
keyPoints: Incomplete combustion produces CO, C, H2O
Complete combustion produces CO‚ÇÇ, H2O only
Soot on the can indicates incomplete burning
Adequate oxygen supply ensures complete combustion

specific_heat_capacity.title: Specific Heat Capacity
specific_heat_capacity.content: Specific heat capacity (c) is the energy required to raise 1 gram of a substance by 1¬∞C. Water has c = 4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π, which is unusually high, making it ideal for calorimetry.
keyPoints: c(water) = 4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π
Units are Joules per gram per degree
q is heat energy in Joules
Convert J to kJ by dividing by 1000

food_energy_units.title: Food Energy Units
food_energy_units.content: Food energy is measured in kJ g‚Åª¬π (kilojoules per gram) rather than kJ mol‚Åª¬π because foods are mixtures of many substances with no single molar mass.
keyPoints: Foods are mixtures, not pure compounds
kJ g‚Åª¬π allows comparison regardless of composition
Food labels often use kJ per serve or per 100g

fat_energy_value.title: Energy Value of Fats
fat_energy_value.content: Fats and oils provide 37 kJ g‚Åª¬π, more than double that of carbohydrates or proteins. This is because fats have more C-H bonds (are more 'reduced') and release more energy when oxidised.
fat_energy_value.formula: Fat energy = mass of fat √ó 37 kJ g‚Åª¬π
keyPoints: Fats = 37 kJ g‚Åª¬π (highest)
More C-H bonds = more energy
Body stores excess energy as fat
High fat foods are energy-dense

protein_energy_value.title: Energy Value of Proteins
protein_energy_value.content: Proteins provide 17 kJ g‚Åª¬π, placing them between fats and carbohydrates. The body preferentially uses proteins for building and repair rather than energy.
protein_energy_value.formula: Protein energy = mass of protein √ó 17 kJ g‚Åª¬π
keyPoints: Proteins = 17 kJ g‚Åª¬π
Used mainly for structure, not energy
Only used for energy when carbs depleted
Made of amino acids

carbohydrate_energy_value.title: Energy Value of Carbohydrates
carbohydrate_energy_value.content: Carbohydrates provide 16 kJ g‚Åª¬π, the lowest of the three macronutrients. However, they are the body's preferred energy source because they are quickly digested and metabolised.
carbohydrate_energy_value.formula: Carbohydrate energy = mass of carbs √ó 16 kJ g‚Åª¬π
keyPoints: Carbohydrates = 16 kJ g‚Åª¬π (lowest)
Includes sugars and starches
Quick energy source
Body's preferred fuel

water_no_energy.title: Water Provides No Energy
water_no_energy.content: Water contributes zero energy to food because it cannot be oxidised further. High water content dilutes food, reducing its energy density (kJ per gram of total food).
keyPoints: Water = 0 kJ g‚Åª¬π
Water is already a combustion product
High water foods have low energy density
Water adds mass but no energy

fat_highest_energy.title: Why Fat Has the Highest Energy
fat_highest_energy.content: Fats contain more carbon-hydrogen bonds per gram than carbohydrates or proteins. When oxidised, C-H bonds release significant energy, making fats the most energy-dense macronutrient.
keyPoints: Fats are highly reduced (many C-H bonds)
Carbohydrates already contain oxygen
More oxidation = more energy release
This is why the body stores fat for energy

food_energy_calculation.title: Calculating Total Food Energy
food_energy_calculation.content: To find total energy in food: multiply each macronutrient's mass by its energy value (37, 17, or 16 kJ g‚Åª¬π), then add all contributions. Divide by total mass to get kJ g‚Åª¬π.
keyPoints: Calculate each macronutrient separately
Add all energy contributions
Water and fibre contribute no energy
Divide by total mass for energy density
